name: Garry's Mod
description: Garry's Mod is a physics sandbox. There aren't any predefined aims or goals. We give you the tools and leave you to play.

Garry's mod...Aah, what can we say about this little gem? This beautiful not-really-a-game-game gives you some of the most open Sandbox software ever. Not only does it give you the power to change physics and spawn gazillion NPCs at the same time, it has spawned a few of the most brilliant gamemodes, such as Trouble In Terrorist Town (TTT) and Prop Hunt. Both are absolutely hilarious, these fairly small items already make it an EPIC piece of software. Then there's Sledding, Gmod Tower and countless others that make it even more amazing. G'mod's a gem, don't even hesitate to get this one!

Amazing game, but remember, it's only as good as the addons you put into it. The very basic singleplayer itself is fun, but lacking in parts as a sandbox game. However, this can be fixed by a quick visit to the workshop, where you will be able to find virtually any addon you wish. Do you want to parachute out of a Black Hawk while quickscoping Osama bin Laden in the head? You can do that. Do you want to nuke a base made completely out of couches, during a slow mo sequence? That is also possible. There are also many multiplayer servers, ranging from sandbox, to Roleplay, to TDM, or to Trouble in Terrorist Town. Virtually every sort of multiplayer experience possible is in this game. The multiplayer games have themes like Zombie survival, or military life, and arcade deathmatch. However, it should also be noted, there are MANY bugs. While these bugs are virtually non existant in vanilla singleplayer, you WILL encounter them once you download some addons. Having many addons will slow down the game load speed, if you're on a low-end computer. 9/10.

The 'game' known as 'Garry's Mod', is not a game, it is actually a highly effective time travel program which was secretly stolen from the U.S government by the infamous hacker Garry Newman. The exact purpose of the game is uknown but most agree that by running the program you will be teleported anywhere from 2 hours to 3 days into the future.    Because the program, which is known as 'Garry's Mod' was stolen while it was still unfinished: Leading to the biggest problem in the program: It may randomly crash at any moment. The U.S secretely gave Garry amnesty for his crime in return for not telling VALVe that they had not reimbursed them for using the Source engine in the development of the project.   I advise you to avoid Garry's Mod entirely because playing it often results in these side effects: Withdrawl after play, Major Obsession, Self-Neglect, Self-Mutilation (typically when the game crashes), Emotianally Distant, and sever Cravings.  Do not let what happened to me happen to you. Do not play this game.

This is the game you literally cannot be bored of. At least I know I can't. Other games are good and all, and might have some good mechanics and maybe even a brilliantly crafted story. But Garry's Mod takes the cake in my opinion. Garry's Mod doesn't need any of that fancy stuff, because it already HAS it. You can literally do ANYTHING. From nuking your entire map, to taking in game selfies with your friends, Gmod is capable of anything. The countless mods, the countless maps and weapons and NPCS all make the game what it is. It is just such an incredible game. I know what you're thinking, 'why is this guy going on and on about this sandbox game?' Well, my answer is, because I simply, truly, absolutely, love this game. It is the 'do whatever the hell you want game', it is awesome.   So, if you have $10 on steam, don't get undertale, get Gmod :)    (yes I do realize the graphics aren't the best, but it's still great)

Actually this game is very famous so a review is not that important.  Garry's Mods real sense is to simulate physics and to be a sandbox game. When you play it like it this I agree that it can be fun but it's more fun if you play other gamemodes.  First of all, there is Trouble in Terrorist Town. In this gamemode you have to uncover traitors or as a traitor you have to kill the innocents. That's a really short describtion but it's basically it. TTT is a great gamemode to play for several hours at a time.   Secondly, there is Prophunt. In Prophunt you have whether to hide as a prop or to find the fake props. This gamemode makes a lot of fun as well as TTT.   Last example is Deathrun. Like the name says, this gamemode is about to run away from the death or actually to run and avoid the death. Deathrun is a bit more difficult sometimes and has a decent rate of despair often. Nevertheless, it's fun!  Of course all of these gamemodes require friends to play with.  So if you want to play funny games with your friends and only buy one game then get Garry's Mod

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

From TTT to DarkRP, Garry's Mod is the one game that you can really do anything with (sort of) realistic graphics. Want to play a Zombie Survival Gamemode? Done. Want to do a survival gamemode(like minecraft and Rust, but just smaller)? Done. The point I'm trying to get across is that when you buy this game, you can technically call it buying a bunch of games. To me, this is just the kick-off point of the game. Games like Murder and Slender are fairly new gamemode.Oh and dont forget the Workshop! The community is great. Which, is actually where you install some of the game modes. Also, the classic sandbox mode is a great way to get used to the game. From the workshop, I can spawn in a dubstep gun in sandbox mode and spawn in a few NPC's to test it on. So, anyhow, if you are looking for a game with a wide choice of playing, choose this game. You won't regret it.

My review of Garry's Mod (Singleplayer only):  What do I know about Garry's mod... well, it's a tool for posing, making screenshots and showing off screenshots which look to be processed through movie filters. Often, if using the right graphics card, a picture can look crisp, clean and even outperform Source Film Maker in terms of quality.  However, there is one massive downfall that Garry's mod regularly faces, this downfall is its addons, not that the content is bad, a large majority is awesome to say the least. But, the real downfall is that there seems to be NO MEANS of accessing any content you have subscribed to on the workshop sometimes. That's what really makes it fall down MASSIVELY.  As an example, you might be biding your time casually playing around in a different game when suddenly, WHAM! A bolt of pure inspiration hits you, you happen to have the skill and the addons to make your wildest dreams come true! But then, you load up Garry's Mod and check to see if all your mods are there...  ...You see that it says 'NO MODS FOUND!' it is more common to find your game unmodded due to errors regarding either the workshop or the game itself, and it's rather dull without the mods, as you have very limited resources to play with, even if it's a sandbox game. Truth is, the game is still confined to all the items within the Source engine, these mods allow you to completely bypass this reliance as long as you have the neccessary Source textures.   So you're probably wondering... why the hell would someone buy a game that's so plain, boring and buggy?  Well, let me give you an answer, the community. There are literally BILLIONS of mods for Garry's mod that exist as of this current moment in time, there is also a random peice of information that I happen to know and it's the following:  At least one thing is submitted to the Garry's mod workshop every 0.5 seconds at least.  This means that the workshop is still growing, even now whilst you are reading this. But that's not all that's on offer, you have the whole internet at your fingertips (trust me, google is your friend). If you are ready and willing to sift through all the bad stuff and find the huge goldmine of good stuff, it'll be incredibly enticing to buy Garry's mod.  Overall, I'd say YES to reccommending this game, but I'd attempt to get it at a discounted price from somewhere... it's not bad, but it's not exactly value for money either.

Garry's Mod is the best sandbox game ever. You can do anything in it, from building in sandbox to messing around in other gamemodes made by the community. Garry's Mod itself can be boring but it will never get boring with the all of the addons made by the community. You can do anything you can imagine, you can download a roller coaster save in a map & have fun in it with friends, you can survive zombie hordes in zombie survival gamemodes, you can watch videos with your friends in Cinema gamemode. It's so addicting & fun, Garry's Mod will never get boring as long as the workshop of it is alive. This game is pretty fun & funny with friends. It's fun while playing solo too. A must play for any gamer.  Note - You'll most likely face a lot of texture errors (pink & black) & error signs in multiplayer because most servers use Counter-Strike: Source content. So it's recommended to buy the CS:S+GMod package/bundle. But if you don't have money, you can download the content for free.  Recommended source games for the best experience in multiplayer : 1. Counter-Strike: Source 2. Half-Life 2 3. Half-Life 2 episode 1 & 2  Rating - 10/10.

Absolutely brilliant game. Never once have I regretted buying Gmod. If you're looking for anything long term, or just something to waste time on, look no further! The base game itself is a sandbox game. You could spend your time building amazing things (or not so amazing things, there have been a lot of ♥♥♥♥♥ rockets built o.o). But if you aren't into building things, worry not! There are plenty of gun packs to download for free, pre-set vehicles to have fun in, and much, much more! As for multiplayer, there are a lot of different things to choose from. There are the simple and well known things such as Murder, Trouble in Terrorist Town, Prop Hunt, Hide and Seek, but there are also more complex things such as roleplaying and survival servers (having different themes such as zombie, post-apocalyptic, or just general surviving.) I would definately recommend buying this game, because it is honestly loads of fun. If you're more if the social type, bring a friend, or friends! This is one of those games where it is quite easy to make memories of awesome, and hilarious all-nighters with your buds. But if you're more if the lone wolf, you can easily still make as many memories of amazingly (or horrendously terribly) built devices of your imagination. Silly or serious, team-player or loner, dedicated or laid-back, this is the game for you!

Garry's Mod is sandbox game, you shouldn't expect anything very big.  So let's start from workshop, on GMod workshop you could find a huge amount of pointless, poorly made Dupes/Saves/Weapons that are just same and same category(A good example could be M9K or FNAF, yes you dont get to see anything special very often), but if you get to see addon that someone put effort in and didn't used a template, author must be experienced.  Most of servers are just s***, having only Coderhire and random Workshop addons, but if you get to see a server with most of stuff self-made and without 12-years old admins, you shouldn't miss it.  Community is filled with 12-years olds(especially on sales), Thought they're uncommon on not-so-popular servers, but if you get to see a good community that doesn't just bans you for smallest mistakes, you still shouldn't miss it(Even in Garry's Mod, you could meet your worst nightmare, '12-years old server owner').  But, unlike most of sandbox games, Garry's Mod could be edited to any other game genre, a good example could be Prophunt, where 'Props' have to hide from 'Hunters' by changing their model to any physics prop they could find.  Also, GMod could be a good alternative to SFM, since in GMod Sandbox, you could pose 'ragdolls'(character bodies) to any pose, and with specific tools you could really make something really interesting.  And the final rating is: 9.5/10 - Garry, you should listen to your community and stop making money off Rust(which is another story).  Oh, before i forget, you also need Counter-Strike: Source to play most of gamemodes(just to don't see at bunch of black-and-purple checkers or 'ERROR' signs).

A positive of the game is that it is essentially an engine where many other games can exist, so while I have played this game the most out of any other game I have ever owned in my Steam library, it is really a game with many smaller games inside of it so it never gets 'old'. For it's price it is an amazing game which you will play for years to come but after playing this game for over 1000 hours I can begin to see it's faults. Garry's Mod is a physics sandbox. Unlike regular games there aren't any predefined aims or goals. We give you the tools and leave you to play.   You spawn objects and weld them together to create your own contraptions - whether that's a car, a rocket, a catapult or something that doesn't have a name yet - that's up to you.   If you're not too great at construction - don't worry! You can place a variety of characters in silly positions  You can go on servers with different gamemodes its amazing.

If you like to use your brain a bit and create odd machines out of random scrap or if you just want to make some silly screenshots using props and characters from other Valve titles then this is the game for you.   At its core, Gmod is a sandbox style game where you are given various props, characters and construction materials and you are given the tools to place and fuse them together in a variety of ways. With those tools, you can make odd contraptions and vehicles or you can just place objects and characters to make silly scenes for screenshots or videos. Want to slap some car tires on a bath tub and have a race with your buddy? No problem. Want to construct a massive robot out of refrigerators and washing machines? Possible, if difficult. It is all up to you really.  However, Gmod can be as complicated as you want it to be. With extensions like wiremod and other mods you can really get in-depth with the engineering/coding and design things like automatic machine gun turrets. Some of the built-in construction materials also lend themselves to building rather complex machines and structures.   Gmod also has rather good integration of the Steam Workshop and you can use it to share your own creations or to check out other player's stuff. Gmod is most assuredly a game for the creative mind to express itself in a variety of ways.

This game is not fun with Singleplayer, you can spent here over 1 hour and then you get bored, but if you have friends who can play with you its really fun. Also this game is development tool, whinch you create custom entities,wepons, vehicles and lot of stuff, where you using LUA(Jit) scripting language, to play with game engine. You can make here machinima as well. (After SFM release, rip GMOD) There's a lots of tool and stuff here, thats, why I calling this game multipurpose.

Garry's Mod is a game for 2 types of people. The first type, is people who like creating things. You can create nearly anything in the source engine, with the right addons, and if you aren't very good, there are youtube videos on it all. I got into this game after the main yogscast channel showed off the addon pack for making space ships. I spent hours in this, and using the base creation tools, before I found out how awesome the multiplayer gamemodes are. I am not sure how many are made by Facepunch studios, but it is through their work that so many are able to easily experience projects made by single people, or budding indie devs of the future. The other types of people are those who spend all of their time on Trouble in Terrorist Town, or Murder, or Prophunt, or any of the main game modes. Heck, you and your friends can walk into a virtual cinema and watch all of SeaNanners's and the yogscast's videos to learn about them! This game has everything apart from what you can imagine. All you have to do is make it.
Fun to play, great game play, and thousands of mods. What could be better?
To sum this game up shortly: It's a game where you can do anything. Be it shooting, RP, or creating something awesome. It covers a wide spectrum of game types.

Garry's Mod (GMod) Developed by Garry Newman in his Facepunch Studios, is a Source engine powered sandbox game that is unbelievably funny.  Released it 2004 (same year when Source engine was released) and it wasn't been forgotten since. 1,000+ funny and useful addons to download in the Steam Workshop. You can do literally anything with the .lua and Source engine combined such as modelling and scripting.  The not-so recent 13 update broke almost every addon that existed. But also added ALOT of new features. Such as Kinect controlling.  Garry's Mod is an unforgettable game that made internet so funny with G-Man and TF2 classes.  Main objective of this game is having fun and wasting time with friends or doing posters/videos.
I love this game as you can see, the amount of fun is endless. And the servers are amazing. I DEFINETLY RECCOMEND THIS GAME TO ANYONE.

After playing for over 1,200 hours, you'll learn a few things. For Multiplayer: Multiplayer can be a wonderful experiance that will forever change you, create friendships and learn new ways to express yourself via creation.  1. Never use the Kleiner Skin 2. No how matter much you hate the map, it'll will always be there on a Server 3. Dont expect sympathy if your new, but if you are, be friendly, dont act like you just learned how to use a computer last week.  4. Somebody will always be better at building than you, but dont stop yourself from characteristic things that really say You, You Made this. This is what I am.  5. Somebody will always be more notable than you, for better or worse. 6. You'll always meet that one guy who is a master at almost everything, but akward to be around. Chances are they are an Admin 7. Servers with custom ranks are guranteed to be a little sketchy 8. More often than not, somebody will scream out DarkRP rules on your sandbox server. 9. Ever hear the phrase RDM where it doesnt belong? Note Note 8 10. All Admins have different personalities, and odds are, you cant please all of them. Stick to rules 3 and 4. 11. Admins may have a Domino effect, so try to please atleast one as a friend. 12. Quality over Quantity? Who says? 13. DONT. Be. A child. You are guranteed to get muted or hated, unless your playing on respective, child friendly servers. This means anyone under 12. 14. You could have 400 addons. But each server you join is going to have atleast 10 things for you to get. This could go on forever, rules and situations in which they'd apply. But Id reccomened Gmod for anyone looking for an experiance unlike any other.

Garry’s Mod (GMod) is the ultimate sandbox that lets you create your own experience, whatever you want that to be. Launching back in 2006 the game has seen steady success in that time selling millions of copies through the Steam platform.  To take your sandbox experience one step further Garry’s Mod also offers ragdoll options where you can bring in a model from a Source game and pose it in a variety of ways. This feature has proven popular with video makers in particular as it easily lets you create your own machinimas.  For those that want to play around with physics instead you’ll also find a realistic physics engine backing up the GMod experience which creates hours of fun as you test your creations.   Of course robust multiplayer is an important element to the Garry’s Mod experience with plenty of servers always online and a large community constantly creating new things both for and with Garry’s Mod thanks to the Lua scripting language (also used in Roblox).  For both creators and players Garry’s Mod has a lot to offer and its popularity still stays strong even many years after its first release, a testament to how great the experience is. In conclusion, download this game right now!

Garry's mod is one of those Rare games that you can play again and again and never really bore of. You can find other games, and invest hundreds of hours into them, but at the end of the month, you find yourself wishing you could just play some more Garry's Mod. I don't have over 450 hours into it for nothing, and, compared to some of the people I've met and talked to over the internet, that's not even that much to invest into a single game.  It's setup into different gamemodes. There's classic sandbox, where you can build and screw around on any amount of maps, with NPC's and other Mechanics. There's Trouble in Terrorist Town (TTT), where a few people are randomly selected as 'traitors', and try to kill the other players on the server, while 'innocents' and 'detectives' are trying to figure out who the Traitors are. I owned a Server for TTT, and I have to admit most of my hours are into asmuch.  A few things to note; First off, it's not the most well-optimized game out there. I have quite an expensive computer, but it still takes forever to load into the game, and will crash periodically, for no reason. I used to play on a DarkRP server (another gamemode) called Serious Roleplaying Hell, or SRH for short, and while that thing had a 'hell' of a lot of 'serious' items for 'roleplaying' (I am so sorry), the game lagged the devil out of itself, while a lot of games would be able to handle something like that without too-much-trouble.  Another thing to keep in mind is that it has Workshop support. Maps, NPC's, Models, Ragdolls, Machines, Weapons, and loads of other Misc. Content fills Garry's Mod, and has been on the second page of Workshop contributators for a while, if not the first one.  Overall, between the content, the Price (especially 2+ years later, when the price has dropped $10), all the dfferent gamemodes (Besides Sandbox, TTT, and DarkRP, there is also Prophunt, Murder, a DayZ Spinoff, and countless others), it's a great game that's totally worth it.  Cheers!

This game is fantastic, but kills brain cells. Just beware of the bugs that this game has, such as: Console bug; everytime you open console it may or may not crash! Yay!; Memory bug: If a major game function is stuck on a loop, it'll take a lot of RAM. No joke. In order to fix this, you must restart the game. Or let it crash. Next up, and finally this is the last of the major bugs, The physics bug: Source Engine never expect a game like this to be created, so you'll find lots of rather funny bugs, and lots that are simply useless and need to be fixed. Oh well, nothing will change the fact that Source Engine was horribly written, and given any chance, and programmer (including me), could fix it. It's not FUBAR, just really ♥♥♥♥♥♥. But all in all, the game is fun, halarious, crazy, and time consuming. I'd recommend it to anyone. Just beware of the bugs I've mentioned, they are real and common. Yes, you will be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if you're hauling money in dark RP, and then you get this awesome idea to make binds for ♥♥♥♥ and so on, so bam you go to open console and CRASH! Just don't break anyhting, you'll get use to it sooner or later. One more thing, this game does have great memory. If you load into a server more than once, each time you'll load faster. The first time you may have to download stuff, the next you'll have it, you may go from hours on the first load, to minutes on the next, to seconds after the 30th load in. It's always nice to know gmod has SOME level of niceness. Whatever, just get the damn game and enjoy it, you'll love it. Just keep your addons on the low, and it breaks often.

Where should i start off... well the bad things about Garry's Mod are the dreaded pink and black missing textures. To fix this, either buy the Counter Strike GO game or get the textures online and copy/paste files. That's pretty much all i can say for the cons of G-mod. There are so many good things about Garry's Mod i cant explain them all in one review so here are some of them: There are many gamemodes to play such as Sandbox [Build whatever you want or kill people], Zombie RP [Roleplay with zombies!], Dark RP [Roleplaying for your satisfaction], Prop Hunt [As a prop, hide somewhere where you wont be seen; As a hunter hunt down the hidden props but watch your health!], and so much more. If you dont like the normal Half Life 2 guns or style of it just go check out the wonderful addons for G-mod! There is so many addons such as TDM Cars [Realistic cars], The Slow Motion Mod [When activated makes everything go in slooooooww moooottiiiiooooon], World War 2 Soldiers [WWII soldiers textures, NPCs, and skins], and so much more. So, there is only one question: 'Is it worth my money?' And the answer is 'Yes! definetely get it!'

The great game

(Short Verison at the Bottom)  I feel that this is among the greats here on steam. It has one of the most active and varied communities of any game I’ve ever played, and for the most part a good community at that (if you don’t like voice chat I’d recommend against playing on RP servers). The game is great if you have no idea what to do due to its vast array of content both official and community made. It’s also very easy to get into with clear labeling of all the tools you have at your disposal (Although it can get very complex and time consuming if you let it). Overall a amazing game for pretty much any type of gamer due to its shear amount of content (which is unmatched in my opinion by any other game on steam). Furthermore it’s not incredibly expensive for the base game, but BUYER BEWARE you will need all the source games in order to have the FULL experience; although it’s very easy to have fun with none of them or very few such as CS: Source and, TF2 (these are all you really need if you want to play online to the full experience). I personally would recommend this game to everyone I know that has ANY interest in a physics based sandbox with combat elements or just to mess around. For the price it’s a great game to look into, and it goes on sale often so even if you don’t pick it up at full price consider getting it during a sale.  SHORT REVIEW: Pro's: Good physics engine  Near unlimited content (workshop) Easy to get into Great multiplayer (lots of modes) Good price for the amount of content Single player is just as good Ability to have complete freedom over what you do (Great Sandbox gameplay)  Cons: (May) Have to buy additional games to have to complete experience Mic spam Poor combat model Graphics are dated in some places Resource intensive (may need a good computer) May need to download packs for servers manually Greifing is common in some multiplayer game types Little help from ingame tutorials (Lots of tutorials online)

Garry's mod is only as fun as your imagination, at least in sandbox mode. Some of the other game modes (eg. Murder, Prophunt, TTT) can be fun, but it seems to me a lot of people are a bit of a wet blanket when it comes to TTT.  Some of the 'house rules' a lot of servers seem to set detract from the fun. If I see 5 people holed up in a room with no intention of trying to find the traitor/murderer, why shouldn't I be able to stir them up so the game can actually continue into the next round? or if I saw someone kill someone else, why do I have to compose a three page essay to 'prove it'?  So yeah, if you don't mind the draconian conditions or possible bordom due to lack of imagination, Garry's Mod and it's multiple game modes are okay. 'What is it?' is probably the most frequently asked question about G-Mod. This ever changing game has left many with that question unanswered. Today we seek to have that question answered. Today we will leave that question unanswered. Welcome to Garry's Mod.  I suppose I should start with the gameplay. That is just the unique thing about G-Mod though. It has no one set gamemode. The whole point of G-Mod is to test, create, and try out the many different gamemodes you can download from the Steam Workshop. They are fun and there is a great variety to chose from. The game also comes with two preloaded gamemodes. Trouble in Terrorist Town and Sandbox. Sandbox is basic build/do whatever you want gamemode, while Trouble in Terrorist town is a murderer/detective style gamemode. Both are fun and intuitive. The sandbox gamemode gives you more freedom, but has a bit of a larger learning curve. The Trouble in Terrorist Town gamemode is a bit more for those who are accustomed to games like Unreal Tournament or Counter-Strike. I personally prefer playing on the Sandbox gamemode as it allows you to build anything you want via the tools provided within the Source Engine.   You might still be wondering: 'What exactly do you do in Garry's Mod?' Well to answer your question, just about anything you want! That is what makes Garry's Mod so amazing...the freedom limited by unlimited boundaries.  Now as for the graphics. They are good. The Source Engine does an excellent job of creating a beautiful, fluid, and realistic world. For being an engine almost 10 years old it still does not falter in it's quality.  The sound is anything but a disappointment. It is loud, powerful and moving. Because this is primarily a Sandbox game it gives the user freedom to add on their own sounds or sound effects from the workshop. I cannot tell you how many times I have been playing on some kind of a Horror Map and the key element was the loud and pulsing sound. A screech coming from behind, sounds like a real screech from behind.   Ok, now for Lasting Appeal. Ummmm...hmmmm. About as unlimited and ongoing as you want it to be. Simple as that.  All in all, this is a great game for Minecraft lovers (14 and up :) and Source Engine developers alike. Why? Well...cause it's G-Mod of course! And what is that exactly? Well, let's not go down that road...  Overall Rating: 8/10  Presentation: 9/10 Multiplayer: 6/10 Gameplay: 7.5/10 Graphics: 7/10 Sound: 8/10 Lasting Appeal: 10/10  Overall Rating: 8/10

Garry's Mod. Well, there's a lot I can say about this 'game'. It started as a simple modification, and it's now one of the most popular games on Steam. How, you ask? Because it's  Open Source.  [en.wikipedia.org]  Sure, the game has its cons, like times where framerate gets bad, but there's a lot of fun to be had, like constructing things with friends, or roleplaying on DarkRP.  -Pros- >Expansive list of Gamemodes. >Completely user-populated. >Never the same experience. >Co-op playability. >Overall, a fun experience.  -Cons- >Large amount of griefers. >Underage mic spam. >Immaturity. >Framerate loss (at times). >At least 1 source game required (TF2 counts, but I strongly suggest CS:S). >Crashes relating to addons.  Despite the cons, this game is worth checking out. I hope you enjoy playing this, and have fun! (Source: 1,693.4 hours.)

Do you love sandbox games, if so trust me your going to love this game. This game does require a Source game to play. So to start off your new sandbox adventure start off with the free Source game TeamFortress 2. The more Source games you own the more powerful your game becomes, because with more sources of games the more items there are to use. Now we all know there are millions of add-ons for this game thanks to the community, and of course not all of them are going to work. Dont let that bring you down, its not that hard to learn LUA (the coding launguage for most add-ons in Garry's mod.) Games I reccomend having for this game: Half-life 2, Half-life 2: episode 1, Half-life 2: episode 2, Counter strike: source, Team Fortress 2, Left 4 dead, Left 4 dead 2. Keep in mind you need to have them installed for them to work on Garrys' mod.  Now this game does take time to learn how to use your tools, and phys gun (the main tool for prop, ragdoll, or really anything) manipulation. If needed go check out some tutorials online. Once you understand the basics the limits are up to you. Using anything, (from the Source games you have installed to your pc), to create anything you desire. This game is incrediable, easy to make servers allow you and your friends to play. Using the Community made add-ons bring in things that are not already in the game to your hands, well your in-game hands. Create things and share them with the Community, your options are only limited to your imagination. Using the Source engine, Garry's mod is one of the best sandbox games, in my personal opinion.  Now grab your chair, turn off your alarm clock, call in sick for work, make sure you mouse has batteries, just in case grab a spare, put your phone on silent, now pre... wait grab some drinks and food. NOW, press buy, then install and click play........ Your new sandbox adventure has just started.

[+] Many gamemodes [+] You can play games or play sandbox creating a scene [+] Billions of addons downloadable from in-game menu or just from Steam workshop. You want to have that weapon - just download it. You don't want to have? Don't download! Best $10 I've ever spent. You can tell that a game is good when it is still getting over, what, 100,000 players after like 8 years at least. This is a very open source game for beginner+ programmers who want to get some experience with working with coding and such (Beginner programmers, Google Notepad+ to view and edit some files found in Garry's Mod, such as 'lua' files.).  For players who just want to create stuff, destroy stuff, and have a good time with friends, Garry's Mod is the perfect game for you. Want more memes? Check out the workshop for Garry's Mod, packed with over 700,000 weapons, maps, props, player models, NPC's (Non Playable Characters. Aka: Bots, Computer controlled players, etc.), and more!   Want various game modes? Done. There are tons of fun, strategic, and funny game modes available for Garry's Mod to make your experience that much better! Best of all, it's made by the community! Everyday players create these exciting game modes for your entertainment (creators of content are not required to make game modes, so don't go demanding it from them and threaten to contact the developers of Garry's Mod, because the community wasn't hired by FacePunch, so they won't come charging in to the rescue just because of that.) ~~~~~~~~~Edit: My old review sucked, so let's rewrite it, shall we?   Garry's Mod is a game in which you utilize the whole Source Engine that we have come to love. You can build on maps that have been preloaded for building creations so wacky and enevitably crash your computer from a prop that accidently got welded to the floor. So, what do you do when you have finished all of the wacky stuff you can do alone? You add more people! You can host servers from a plethera of gamemodes that are made by the players, for the players. So what if you were building a roller coaster that became so boring that you thought of just ditching the idea? Now you can have people that know how the game works and teach you how to make them actually work, and make you go from Falcon Punch to Facepunch! (Sorry, one bad pun quota is needed for a game as silly as this!) Make new friends or tragic enemies as they blowup your building made completely out of wood! But you can get revenge in some of the most albeit bizarre gamemods that you have seen! Seriously, there are too many for me to list, just buy the game with Counter Strike: Source... please?

No game can exactly compare to Gmod. It is incredible. You can do so much and it is so fun. Whether you are sandboxing or playing Trouble in Terrorist Town, you will have lots of fun.  This game has many pros. For starters, the incredible physics engine of Source combined with a sandbox game makes for some fun times. This game can be used for making animations, by spawning in ragdolls and positioning them where you want, and finally snapping a picture. You also get a lot for your $10 worth. Not only do you get sandbox (which is fun in itself) but you also have other games by the modding community build for Garry's Mod. These are games such as Stop it Slender, Trouble in Terrorist Town, Murder, Prop Hunt and many more. However, this game isn't perfect.  This game has a few minor cons that are worth talking about. Firstly, if this is your first Steam purchase, or your first Source game purchase, you may run into a few problems. See, you need to buy a Source engine game. While that wasn't an issue for me (I personally got Steam for Portal once, now I use it much more) others may find themselves not being able to play GMod. Secondly, many of the games require Counter-Strike: Source. This was a problem for me, because I didn't want to pay $20 for CSS. I was able to get the textures off the internet (legally!) and mod my game so this was fixed, however many users may not want to do this. Finally, when you first play this game, you may have no idea what it is exactly, and just play Sandbox, which can get very boring. There's no guide or help to tell you there's anything else to do.  To summerise, GMod is a great game that will keep getting better as it is updated and as the community of modders and other Workshop creators alike grows. However, because of some minor issues, this game deserves an 8.3 out of 10. I recommend this game, and you should definately buy it.

Garry's Mod gives you a ridiculous amount of freedom with tons of ridiculous tools which translates into a lot of ridiculous fun. The huge amount of Workshop content and the ability to do just about whatever you want with it gives this game truly endless potential and diversity. Garry’s Mod, a very large game by Facepunch Studios. It gives you the power to do so much and yet it always ends the same way, with blood splattered on the walls. To describe Garry’s Mod is hard but possible, and in sections is the best way to do it.  Garry’s Mod is all about creation, it was originally designed as a sandbox game, where you can spawn hundreds of props in, weld them together and make incredible things. But that was a long time ago and Garry’s Mod isn’t just a game for welding things, now you can use winches, rope, hover balls, emitters, and a very large assortment of weapons.  The game requires a few other games to be installed to see everything though. Source Mod games, the minimum amount of games you’ll need to see the most are the games; Team Fortress 2, Counterstrike: Source and Half Life: Source. The game can still be played without them but is better with them, you can spawn in props and characters from those games too. If you like the medic from TF2 why not rebuild the ‘Meet The Medic’ video clip.  Over the years of people playing around with Garry’s Mod extra game modes were born; Spacebuild (original mod removed), Trouble in Terrorist Town, Murder, Prop Hunt, DarkRP, Sled Build, Bomber Man and many more. These game modes change the way Garry’s Mod played, from once a game about welding to watermelons together and then blowing them up, to thing like finding a traitor and killing him, running from a knife wielding murderer, hiding as a pot plant in the snow and dropping explosive watermelons hoping to win the game.  Apart from the sandbox, hundreds of servers and many game modes; Garry’s Mod also has Steam Workshop support so you can share your creations, download others and play with them or even change the way the game plays like getting a tool that lets you change the weight of an object, a tool that makes props larger or smaller, a gun that shoots Nyan Cats and nuclear bombs you can strap to awesome looking cars that have thrusters stuck to its rear and have a big ramp in front of it hoping to make a big bang so to speak.  If you’re the type of person who likes building things, this is for you. If you’re the type of person who likes killing people, this is for you. If you’re the type of person who likes running into a war zone with balloons stuck to your ears then this is for you. This game is incredible and fit’s almost everyone’s needs; horror, sandbox, building, strategy, comedy and more.  If I were to follow my normal rules for reviewing games and rating them out of 10. I’d be lowering the rating millions of times over to make it low enough to fit. It is extremely fun and the rating 10/10 is an understatement.

10/10 would lose 400+ prop tank again.  Seriously though, I do recommend this game. Whether you're like me and play this for friends or if you're simply bored, gmod has pretty much everything. When it come to the base game, it is a bit lacking, with some decent enough tools for creativity and a few maps coming with the base game. There is nothing spectacular about any of it, it is very 'meh'. The modding scene, however, is what gives the game life. It was built for modding, or at least it feels like it, with a well done workshop integration and a massive, but albeit toxic, community, you can change things up or do as I did and go way overboard with the mods. Nothing is truly impossible, but it will demand a good chunk of time if you want to get good at something.   THE COMMUNITY

Garry's Mod is one of the best sandbox games around. Weilding the physgun and toolgun, you can do nearly everything. And coding with LUA makes every possiblity endless! Garry's Mod is a great game to pose characters and props and make a really intresting picture. Want some fire in your picture? Ignite an invisible prop! Want to make a moving door with some crates? Weld them together and use the ballsocket tool, button tool, and thruster tool! Feel like fighting a few enemies? Give yourself some weapons and fight some zombies or combine! This game is very instresting in many ways and is strongly suggested to people who like to just play around or like to look at something and feel like you've accomplished something!

Garry's Mod is a pretty awesome sandbox game. There's no limit to the amount of craziness you can make in this game especially with all the mods/addons available in the Workshop.   Garry's Mod also has some of the greatest Mods ever devised; Stargate Carter Addon Pack, Evolution Addon Pack, Cinema Mod, and of course Spacebuild 3.    Pros  + Includes  29  Steam Achievements +  9  Steam Trading Cards + Requirements are very low and can be run on almost any computer + Actively being developed with updates every couple of months or so + Has some of the best Gaming and RP Communities, friendly and helpful all the way!   Cons  - Too many addons can crash or even break your game - Some addons require you to own other source games like CS:S in order to work properly - Some Garry's Mod Servers & Communities are full of stupid raging 12-year-olds - Garry's Mod can randomly become unbalanced/unstable leading to severely low FPS or a game crash   My Rating: 10/10 (Recommended)

Garry's Mod isn't really that much of a 'game'. If we looked at it in detail, it's a sandbox environment. You create and enjoy. Start with building a box, then a car or tank, and then move up to flying a plane -- all made from HL2 objects.  When you get bored of that, you can move into gamemodes. This is what 'gmod' is known for. It's a game within a game. Since garry's mod is open, anyone can code a new game with LUA and run it off a server for people to play on. Try Trouble in Terrorist Town, maybe a roleplay game, or the good old classic build. Whatever you choose, it's your game.  Powered by Source, garry's mod allows for a lot of customization. Building off of the trusted engine, LUA and the workshop expand the sandbox game into truely infinite playtime. Seriously worth the $10 you have sitting in your wallet.  8.5/10

Anybody who is any sort of fan of Valve games must stick this one on their wishlist and grab it when they've got the dough to cherish this game. Garry's Mod, albeit just a utilisation of the standard game engine, playing online on this game shows off how far the community have taken this.  The game engine has been well and truly taken advantage of in a way that has flourished the creativity of gamers everywhere, yielding only a immersive and captivating online experience in modes such as Prop Hunt, Murder and Trouble in Terrorist Town. These game modes take place on well-known Counter Strike: Source maps and give Garry's Mod a familiar feel while uping the social advantages of having such an abudance of creative game modes.  Buying this game will ultimately provide you with enjoyment, and it's one of those games that everybody eventually needs to have. It's smooth and fun, fast-paced and exciting. A great advantage is that you can play it endlessly because there's so many different gametypes that everytime you get bored of one, there's always somewhere else you can go where you feel like you're playing a whole new game altogether.  So, why exactly should you buy it?  Prop Hunt (a Garry's Mod gametype) captures my attention the most; a hub for laughs as players disguise as objects to hide from 'hunters', the team that must eliminate the team disguising as props. It's like the game of hide-and-seek you always wish you had played as a child. It's tremendous.  'Trouble in Terrorist Town' (or 'TTT') is yet another gametype that can be pretty amusing. Basically, you can be innocent or you can be a traitor. The game assigns each person with one of those titles and then from there, nobody knows who is who. However, for the traitors, they see who else is a traitor and who isn't. Unsurprisingly, their job is to kill (without being caught), and it's fun trying to find out who the traitors are!  'Murder' is similar to TTT in a way that everybody appears the same. There's only one murderer, though, but nobody knows who it is, and only a select couple of bystanders (people who aren't the murderer) get a weapon. It's perhaps the most realistic simulation of being in a mental institution I have ever seen.  That's just a taste of Garry's Mod; due to its lively community, the creativity of what people can do with the Valve game engine is simply constant, and there's always something new to try.

This game is a revolution in the source engine and clearly shows it from the moment you join a server. That being said there are some issues that new players should be warned about, such as prop spamming lagging the game once you reach approximately 7000 props (only applicable in single player) so don't go trying to build a whole city from individual bricks :P The game also lacks performance server side due to compatibility with dedicated servers being 'Garbage' thus making it increasingly difficult to create a server let alone run a decent server with a decent prop limit. The positives however, far outweigh the negatives, making up for the difficulty found when creating a server by ensuring that, as long as your internet connection is above 500Kb/s, you should experience little if any lag on a server with a player limit of 20. The ability to use other steam games alongside Garry's Mod is another great feature of this game and is essentially the function that divides this game from other similar sandbox games. All in all I believe that Garry's Mod is a game worth buying and will give you hours of enjoyment and will grow to meet the demand of new players and in-game content.

♪Old man in a can-Banana plane-magic train! All sorts of creepy yet awesome thiiiiings!♪  The words for this game can't be easily expressed, seeing as the community for it is so vast in numbers. Everyday, new models and items are uploaded to the GMOD workshop for people to upvote and experiment with.  Whether it be an atomic bomb, or a giant robot which shoots rockets, I can assure you that it will amuse you. The little things in life can sometimes be the most appriciated.   The Multiplayer is even better than single player in my opinion. TTT being the best. Prophunt being a close second.  What is TTT? It is a game mode where you are a terrorist. These guys are surprisingly innocent. However, you have to watch out for the traitors who could shoot you in the face at any given moment in time. The detectives however are on the case! With health, DNA tools that let them find the Traitor, and a variety of special weapons in some servers. But beware! The traitors may or may not have the dreaded prop cannon, or melon gun which can kill you in one hit.  Now don't get me wrong, the Traitors may seem overpowered with a lot of 1-hit KO weapons, but it is all in fun. (Especially when a Traitor somehow manages to completly fail and kill himself.)  My word of advice for beginners to a gamemode such as this? DO NOT RANDOMLY KILL. All servers have mods or admins who will ban you if you get on and begin to 'RDM (Random Death Match)' Innocents, Traitors, and detectives. This isn't fun for others, and will likely end up with you never being able to play on that server again.  I could go on and on about what is so great about this game, but I suggest that you just find out for yourself.  A word of Forwarning however, it would be best if you bought the GMOD and Counterstrike source pack if you want to play TTT. There are patches to play as well, but I find it an honest waste of time.  Get in, and play. Join the fun that is GMOD in all its glory.

After having played well over 350 hours I decided I should write a review. Problem was, I didn't know what to focus my review on. That's just the thing though, Garry's Mod has a TON of different things worthy of writing a review over. It's one of the qualities about the game which many other sandbox games can't compete with.   Game Modes: I checked to see how many game modes showed up on my list just for the sake of the review and counted 63. Granted they aren't all popular, but it goes to show that there's an active community and many different things available to do.   Maps: There are a lot of maps available, some of them are extremely complex and it's pretty amazing. For example, they've taken Five Nights at Freddy's and made it into a map that you can walk around in. That in itself is pretty neat, the real cool thing is you can actually play Five Nights at Freddy's, jump scares and all. There are many other neat things you can find while exploring maps.   Servers: There are hundreds of servers available to play on. Many of them have special perks that make the server even more interesting. I've played on servers that have a point shop, you get points every so often for playing on the server. Then you can buy funny hats, trails or upgrades. There are also servers that also have a 'roll the dice' capability which either helps you win the round or makes it extremely difficult. That being said, there are also a lot of normal servers if you'd just like to get the hang of playing.   Community: Of course there are going to be a ton of raging kids on servers, but there are also a lot of mature people on there too. It depends on the server you play on. More often than not I've joined a game with fun people, so don't let the little kids make you change your mind about the game.  Counter Strike Source: The one complaint I have about this game is you need Counter Strike Source for most map textures. They should warn people that the game requires it to play from time to time. The most frequent question I see asked on servers is 'Why is everything pink and black?' or 'How come the textures aren't working?'.   I could keep on going through the vast amount of game modes and other qualities but I think I'll leave those experiences up for you to discover. :)  Overall: It's a hilarious game, well worth the $30 (including Counter Strike Source). You'll definitely get some good laughs.

As a Director and Actor, I can certainly see the appeal of GMod. It's astounding how many tools are at your disposal, how many items you can spawn in, and the number of pills that change every game session. I mean, you can either make a game about Mario and Captain America questing to destroy the Thunderbird or play unique chase games in the Ghostbuster car or in a Tonka Truck. But is the pure randomness of this game the only thing it has going for it. Is it overrated and is it worth the ten dollar price tag.  No. Maybe. and Maybe.  Maybe I should explain.   The randomness is certainly a major attractive point for players. With many user-created mods to mods from popular Valve games, you've got an unlimated amount of items, weapons, pills, and more to explore. I personally perfer the oddly catorted image of Mario as my skin, looking like a monkey with a Halloween costume. But my brothers perfer Ghost Rider and an Elderly man. Whatever your taste is, there is something for you. The items are very fun to use. Using a gun, you can move most items, rotating them or shooting them off. My personal favorite is a 10 story grave monument that shakes the ground when it lands.  This is an unforgettable game.  But as I look around Steam, I find people sinking 2000+ hours into this game. Is it fun? Hell yes. Is it good for movie making? Yeah. But two thousand hours is a lot, especially if you don't make movies. I feel like I've gotten a good amount of this game from 50 hours, but I play almost purely locally. Global servers are insane. The moderators often resort to limiting items to avoid Internet hell for those on board  Nothing more scary than an insane player with a rocket launcher online.  It is a good, 'game,' but I hear people put this high on their top games of all time. My brothers and I have created games from the multiple maps present and they definatly are fun but nothing I haven't experienced on other games. In short, this game is slightly overrated. Not a bad game, at all, just a quirky game, which some people are into that.  The ten dollar price tag is a concern for me. I feel this game should be no more than five dollars, since it is esentially a toolbox. Luckily, I was able to trade for my copy and I feel that is the way to go if you are feeling like picking this up.   OVERALL: 7/10. This game is defiently a game to at least try with friends once. Even without mentioning the fantastic, Trouble in Terrorist Town, this game has a lot going for it. I would not consider it a classic but it recieves it's own identity when the user created models and imagination shines through. The graphics range from, Ouija-bad, to, Intersteller-good, (cheers if you know exactly what I mean,), the tools are in depth, local multiplayer is a blast when globally, it is a nightmare. The tool system is deep and I highly recommend those going into animation to at least have this in your library.

Uh Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead  Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons sugar 1 tablespoon baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg 2 large eggs, at room temperature 1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature 1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed  Now to make it 1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg. 2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla. 3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat. 4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed 5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed. 6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

Considering this game is only $11 and you can basically find a way to simulate any other game you could find with all of the mods you can download with the fact that it is so incredibly easy to download them (after all, the game is called 'Garry's Mod'), this game is a must-buy for any members of steam. If you have $11, this is what you need to spend it on. The fact that you can do so much in one game makes it superior to a lot of other $60 games you would find on the steam store. The graphics are decent, the gameplay play is excellent, there is an infinite amount of replay value, and the community is great. What more could you ask for in a game  However, if you plan to play multiplayer, you will usually need textures. Really, the only 2 or 3 texture packs you will need for most servers are the Counter Strike: Source Textures, The Counter Strike: Global Offensive textures, and the Team Fortress 2 Textures. The only way to get these textures are buying the games. I myself do not have Counter Strike: Source, only Global offensive, and usually servers are very playable with just that. And besides, Counter Strike: Global Offensive is worth the $8 it usually goes on sale for. Team fortress 2 is free, and is another excellent game, so you shouldn't need to worry about that unless you do not have space on your computer for it.  Overall, that is the only problem I have ran into with this game. The rest of it I really enjoy, and was very happy to leave a review for the creators.  Overall, this game is definitely a 9.5/10. I would definitely recommend this masterpiece, and whoever is reading this who hasn't bought this game already, what are you waiting for?

Sandbox mode is the actual standard mode in which you can build everthing you want, you can save your creations and load it in another map, also you can just load creations from other people. For example TTT in which there is one or multiple traitor(s) in a group of terrorist, the traitor(s) has/have to wipe out all terrorists and the terrorists have to wipe out the traitor(s). *  Conclusion: Gmod is a must have, you won't regret it. *I really recommend you buying the Garry's Mod + Counter Strike: source pack because many textures from CSS are being used in the game, otherwise you'll get black/purple colored textures.

This game is a must have for almost any kind of steam user. Though the fun is starting to die down after 800 hours, that is still saying a lot about how good the game is.  PROS: -Extremely easy to run (It's running on an engine over 11 years old) -Though the graphics are showing age, they are high standards if compared to a 7th generation console -VERY active modding community keeps the game alive (I'll go into more detail on this later. Scroll down if you wish) -Variety of fun and addicting gamemodes, which are still growing in numbers -Player hosted servers (Which is a good thing when you have a lot of them) -A good portion of the community is unserious and goofy, which can be very fun at times -It allows you to pull some content from other Source games (Half Life series, CSS/CSGO, Portal, TF2, etc.) -Playable on all the major computer operating systems -Plenty of servers  CONS: -Is one of those games that steam won't recognize as closed for a while -Some of the community is pretty taint, and either hate younger players, or take things way too seriously -Some bugs after updates, though they get patched within a week, usually -Without Counter Strike: Source, you'll be missing a lot of content for popular communtiy maps, so you'll get a bright purple checkerboard instead, or an error sign  MODDING: This is where the game really shines the brightest. The game's modding capabilities seem almost limitless, and with the Steam workshop you can get a mod with the click of your mouse and some download time. Making a map is simple, and familiar to anyone who has made maps for the Source or Goldsource engines. I haven't gotten any deeper in modding than maps, so I have no idea how hard it is to make those.  The biggest part of the modding has to be the gamemodes. Modders can make entire gamemodes from scratch. These include a lot of well known gamemodes (Due to YouTube popularity) such as Trouble in Terrorist Town (An addicting murder mystery game. Make sure you have Counter Strike: Source for this one, unless you choose to play MC themed maps,) prop hunt (You don't always need CSS for this one, but you'll want it,) DarkRP (It's taken seriously by many but when you get a group of unserious people it's a blast,) and many more gamemodes.  Oh, and there's also an easy to use Local Area Network (LAN) system, that works with any gamemode.

Garry's mod, G-mod for short, is a sandbox type game that offers more than just the ability to run and shoot with buddies. This game places various and amusing tools at your feet for which to have fun with. Spend hours working on a roller coaster with friends, confine yourself to your room and try to build a functioning robot or just spawn some ragdolls and fool around with their faces. Other than just the predetermined gamemode of   Sandbox   there are a variety of other gamemodes , community created, that expand the concept of the game to include first person shooters to roleplaying games. Many hours are to be lost in this wacky game and many fun moments to be created. This game will keep you entertained and smiling on even the worst of days!

Garry's Mod is exactly what it sounds like, a mod for Half-Life 2 made by a guy named Garry. But considering the fact that you're reading this right now, this part of the review is obsolete because I guarantee at least half of you already know that, so that is good, it means that there is still time to save yourself.   Of course, that's scratching the surface. On its own, Garry's Mod is a pretty simple game. You can spawn a couple item props, you can summon a bunch of Half-Life 2 NPCs so you can shoot them in the face, you can even throw props at NPCs and crush them sadistically without any remorse because they don't have a lot of dialogue that sets them apart from a pet cat. You can jump off a skyscraper and take like ten points of damage out of a hundred. You know, pretty simple stuff.   But that is also still just scratching the surface of the mosquito bitten skin, which is easily remedied with lemons. Sure, on its own, you might build a couple wooden boxes and break them because of how unbelievably fragile they are, but Garry's Mod really shines when you add MORE mods. To be specific, the Steam Community Workshop hosts a bunch of weapons, tools, and gamemodes that are made by a bunch of talented, crazy people who create some of the most bizarre, stupid things that should never work logically in a million years, but work in this chaotic mess.   You can spawn a terrorist with a lightsaber which you can battle with a DOOM Super Shotgun. If you want to get into posing but you have no freaking idea how to put the hat on the ragdoll, that is perfectly fine, someone already made a tool for that so that you can place a billion cosmetics on one TF2 Soldier, practically suffocating the poor guy. But hey, he knew what he signed up for, who cares if he looks like a clown? Gotta get those edgy action videos done. You can even download a lemon mod for those who enjoy citrus fruits.   Now, the gamemodes are pretty fun. There are things like Prop Hunt where you can dodge bullets as a can like a sneaky snake but then get blown up by that one jerk who decides to use his SMG grenade or play Trouble in Terrorist Town and never ever find the traitors until you get shot in the face. However, while experiences with gamemodes differ, I would have to offer a warning. Rules on each server vary. While that's agreeable, around half of the admins on DarkRP servers and Sandbox servers are usually something you should avoid. Another thing you should avoid are literally any person you find shady. Doesn't matter how friendly they seem, it usually ends in a shootout. Granted, if the server you are on allows weapons of any sort. But here's a solid tip I find is very helpful for when you want to have fun on a multiplayer server:   Do not join anyone's server. Make your own. Save yourself.   All in all, Garry's Mod is a solid game with a slightly insane player base filled with very passionate people. It's a place to have fun, mess around, and make impractical objects that you can fly to the stars if needed. Except on public servers where half of the fun things you can do is restricted by a myriad of redundant rules and overprotective admins. It's a great game to play with your friends, but an even more chaotic game to play with psychotic Internet strangers.

Uh Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead  Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons sugar 1 tablespoon baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg 2 large eggs, at room temperature 1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature 1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed  Now to make it 1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg. 2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla. 3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat. 4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed 5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed. 6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

I have played this game since I was a little kid, now I'm 18.    Sandbox Physics aside, this game has an immense amount of content, from the maps, the gamemodes, the addons, the what have you, there is SO much to do.   Looking back at it, it's ironic. I was a young kid who older players didn't like playing with, and now I'm an older player who doesn't like playing with younger kids. At least at first, then I realised there's a me in each and every one of them.   Going from gamemode to gamemode, meeting new people, feeling the excitement that I felt playing new gamemodes that are now absolete and therefore dead and forgotten is something I'll always remember. Going from community to community, exploring maps and playing around with content that has been building up for YEARS. It was an amazing experience, being apart of gamemodes like Sassilization for example, that was a gmod topdown RTS that shut down, gamemodes people will never get the chance to play as they're long dead and gone. I imagine that the 12 year olds who ♥♥♥♥ moms now, will eventually keep playing, well into Gmod 2, until the point where they're older screaming at 12 year olds, reminiscing about when their favorite gamemodes were around.  I remember a time when Darkrp didn't have loads of workshop content shoved into the server, where  garrysmod.org  was the main place to get maps and addons, and where my favorite gamemodes were incredibly popular but now are broken and dead.   Nostalgia glasses taken off, it really is an amazing game that you may look back on the same way people look back at Halo 3's Forge, something you have fond memories of that is still around, but somehow not entirely the same.   or maybe it's just some ♥♥♥♥ing game where you can do a bunch of ♥♥♥♥ in idk

There is just so much to do in this game, and so much custimization. Lets start off with the pros of the game. 1. Again, custimization such as, change your playermodel to any addon you've downloaded.  2. The only thing you pay for is the game itself, all mods and addons are completely free which is the best part.  3. Make anything!  4. So many maps to choose from.  5. Great graphics for an older game.  6. NPCs! Fun to mess around with.  7. Online Multiplayer, this is actually my favourite part.  8. Tons of gamemodes to choose from to play either by yourself, locally with a friend or family member, or online with tons of strangers!  9. Chat and Mic enabled!  10. Cheap!  11. Don't need internet to play. Let's say you don't have good enough internet to play online, you can play offline (only by yourself though)  12. Not rated! As in you can be peaceful and kid appropriate or make it as adult rated as any game!  Now the cons,  1. Glitches and bugs, for such a large game with so much to do everybody is going to experience a glitch or bug at some point.  2. Slow at startup and beginning new game.  3. Turn off backround programs as they can stop you from being able to join a local game. Not all backround programs as you'll need a couple to keep your pc from stopping but mailny anti-virus apps and big programs like that.  4. If you're looking to record for Youtube or Twitch its's almost impossible to use a free screenrecorder as alot don't like to (or can't for that matter) record most Steam games. If you want to record for free you'll have to just use a camera and hope the quality doesn't suck. Otherwise you'll have to pay.  5. If you think you don't need to download addons to have fun in this game... You're wrong. Unless you want to sit there with limited ammo, plain old default weapons and shoot at walls in the default maps and maybe hitting a couple default NPCs then be my guest, otherwise you'll be bored sh!tless. You. Need. Addons. But hey! They're free!  6. If you don't want to see a bunch of purple and black checkered, everything, in alot of popular multiplayer games, and addon maps then I reccomend buying. Yes buying, CSgo. What it does is fill in alot of the textures gmod doesn't have originally.  So there it is the pros and cons of Garry's Mod, I see the pros outway the cons so go ahead and try out gmod for yourself, it's worth it.

I'm going to be completely honest about this game. It is stupid, as in weird and fun stupid. This game has no plot or story, only gameplay and visual aspects. So with that out of the way, this is what I think about Garry's Mod.   Graphics: 6.5/10 The visual style of this game is majorly based on Valve's classic Half Life 2. Back then, these graphics were stupendous. Today, however, the game is primitive and overshadowed by games such as Mortal Kombat X or Call Of Duty. These graphics, though, are still decent.  Gameplay: 9.5/10 There are over 25 different minigames made for this particular game. All of them function really well and are a blast to play through. These minigames also spawned versions of themselves in other games such as Minecraft and Call Of Duty 4. Each minigame has its mechanics and all of them feel smooth and fluent.  Support: 7/10 There are well over 6,000 addons being made for this game. Each of them are cool to use, but some of them require additional content, such as having to have Five Nights at Freddy's or Counter Strike: Global Offensive. if you don't have these requirements met, you're stuck with missing textures and sometimes not even being able to launch up Garry's Mod.   Although these mishaps are here, they are minor. Because of this, Garry's Mod recieves an 8/10. It is a must buy at 9.99, and there is so much content. This game will almost never get boring and I strongly recommend it. I've clocked in 292 hours and I don't care.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Having played this game since 2009, I can say that I've seen it grow more and more ambitious with every update. The most notable was the jump from Gmod 12 to Gmod 13 which was packed full of new features which only complemented what I consider to be the [ULTIMATE] sandbox experience. Want to create a fully mobile base that can also fly, shoot lasers and dispense beverages? Want to work together with friends to fight zombies, explore scary co-op maps and play fun minigames like prophunt? This is the game for you.   I could sing this game's praises for quite a while and despite it's flaws (Server owners usually tend to have drama and arguments follow in their wake) I find it to be the best purchase I made on steam to date.   Give it a go.

Has to be one of the best games I've ever played on Steam. When they say anything is possible they aren't kidding. The secret to REALLY enjoying the game would be to find a solid-quality server, meet some friends, and just find different ways of having fun! Trust me when I say there are plenty. The very few negative qualities would be a bit of an overwhelming object-spawn-options menu, but you get used to that quickly. The main other negative that you will probably notice if you spend a bit of time in multiplayer is that in a lot of servers the community can be kind of crap which is why I say it's very important you take a bit of time finding a quality server to spend your time on! I personally reccomend DarkRP, Clockwork Half-Life RP, TTT, and Murder! Some of the more popular game modes anyways, and I enjoy them. Overall I'd say a 10/10 game! Just steer clear of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ servers, familiarize yourself with the way the game works, and you'll be laughing your ♥♥♥ off in no time!

Garrys mod. The best of the best when it comes to sandbox building games. Garrys mod includes a variety of game modes from Trouble in Terrorist town( which is like a find the murderer and dont die type of gam) to role playing) were you pick a job and live the life as if you were that one). With the inclusion of the steam workshop it is even easier to get great addons for your sandbox world. Although it is a great game there are some things to consider before getting, if oyu are on a slow computer it might lag and that will make it hard to play, also servers take a while to load (depending on the mode of choice) and you need to get a few games like Counterstrike, Team fortress 2, and Left for Dead 2 to get some textures unless you want to download them piece by piece. But in all seriousness this game is amazing to have a good laugh with your friends and the gamming community is really friendly for the most part.

Slovak Stuffed Cabbage  YIELD18 Rolls INGREDIENTS  1 Head Green Cabbage 3/4 cup raw rice 3/4 cup water 1 finely chopped medium yellow onion 4 tbsp butter 1 1/2 lbs ground chuck 1/2 lb ground pork or pork sausage salt & pepper 1 large egg 1/2 cup breadcrumbs or panko 2 cloves minced garlic 1 teaspoon carraway seeds 1 tablespoon paprika (sweet or hot) 1 14 oz jar tomato sauce 1 14 oz can crushed tomatoes 20 oz Beef stock (or enough to just cover cabbage rolls) PREPARATION  Pre-heat oven to 350F 1. Core cabbage and place whole head in a large pot with salted, boiling water. Cover and cook 3 mins or until soft enough to pull off outer leaves. Remove leaves and return cabbage to pot for another 3 mins until next layer of leaves soften. You'll need approx 18 leaves. 2. When leaves are cool enough to handles, use a paring knife to remove thick center stem from each leaf, cutting all the way through in a 'V' shape. 3. Rough chop remianing cabbage and placed in the bottom of a large, greased dutch oven. 4. Rinse rice and cook it in water until water has been absorbed. Remove from heat and let cool. 5. Saute onion in butter until tender and cool. 6. In a large bowl, mix cooled rice, cooled onions, beef, pork, egg, garlic, carraway seeds, salt & pepper to taste, paprika, panko and 1/3 of tomato sauce and blend throughly. Dont overmix as meat will become tough. 7. Place about 1/3 of a cup of mixture in each cabbage leaf and flip the sides to seal. Roll away from you to package. Add to dutch oven, seam side down. 8. Layer with remaining tomato sauce top with crushed tomatos. Add enough beef stock to cover rolls. 9. Cover and bake for 2-2 1/2 hours & serve with sour cream (add juice and zest of 1/2 lemon to sour cream to brighten dish a bit)

Definitely a top pick! Never really knew what this game was until I finally played it when a friend recommended it to me. It went on sale and I decided to give it a try, and I can honestly say that I was not disappointed. Garry's Mod is esentially a bunch of smaller games roled into one title. Using Half Life 2 as a base, it edits its gameplay mechanics to create an entirely new experience for players, with even more content and creativity added in by the community. This is definitely a great go-to-game if you have some friends to play with and want an entertaining time waster.
